If the hero chooses, she may make an @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll as an action to increase her horizontal distance by 1″ (2″ with a raise), or half that vertically. Jumping does not allow a character to exceed her total Pace for the turn.
  • PRONE: A character may fall prone as a free action during her turn. She may crawl while prone. Standing is a free action but reduces total Pace for the turn by 2.

Soak Rolls.name: Soak Rolls
Soak Rolls.text:
Soak Rolls

After rolling damage but before applying wounds, a character may spend a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03bennies0000000]{Benny} to make a “Soak” roll. This is a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Vigor} check, with each success and raise reducing the number of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Wounds} suffered from that attack by one.

If the character Soaks all of the Wounds from an attack, he removes his Shaken condition too (even from a previous source). Don’t count the Wound modifiers he’s about to suffer when making this roll—that hasn’t happened yet.

Characters can’t Soak more than once per attack, but may spend Bennies as usual to reroll the Vigor check if they aren’t satisfied with the results.

Shaken: A character can also spend a Benny to immediately eliminate a Shaken condition. This can be done at any time.

Aim.name: Aim
Aim.text:
Aim

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} rolls assume a character is moving about, dodging attacks, and keeping an eye on the chaos around her. If she focuses her attention and aims, however, she can make a much more accurate shot.

If a character spends her entire turn Aiming a ranged weapon at a particular target and takes no other actions, on her next turn she may ignore up to 4 points of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02range000000000]{Range}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03coverandobst00]{Cover}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03calledshots000]{Called Shot}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03sizeandscale00]{Scale}, or @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03speed000000000]{Speed} penalties; or add +2 to her roll. Her attack must be used on the first action of her next turn or the bonus is lost

The shooter must be “stationary” to Aim. She can’t walk, run, ride a horse, or otherwise move under her own power. She could Aim from a vehicle traveling over or through a smooth surface, or one using the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04chasesandveh00]{Hold Steady} Chase maneuver.

Area Effect Attacks.name: Area Effect Attacks
Area Effect Attacks.text:
Area Effect Attacks

Grenades, spell effects, breath weapons, and other attacks that cover a large area are “area effect attacks.” The most common are @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03blasttemplat00]{Small, Medium, and Large Blast Templates, and the Cone Template}. There are copies you can print out on our website and we make durable acrylic versions as well.

Area effect weapons target a location rather than individuals and so ignore defensive bonuses for specific targets covered by the template, such as the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.Dodge]{Dodge} Edge or @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03speed000000000]{Speed} penalties.

Cone templates are placed with the small end emanating from the attacker and fired with the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} skill (or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} for breath weapons and other natural attacks). A basic success means those beneath the template are hit. Failure means the attack didn’t occur for some reason—the creature failed to belch up noxious gas, the flamethrower malfunctioned, etc.

To attack with a blast template, the player places the template on the tabletop (or describes where he wants it to land) and rolls @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting}, or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} for thrown weapons and breath attacks. If the attack fails and there’s a chance it might deviate and hit someone else, see Deviation, below.

If the roll is successful, any target even partially beneath the template is affected, regardless of any attack penalties to hit such as the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.Dodge]{Dodge} Edge. If the effect causes @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{Damage}, roll for each victim separately. Attacks that hit with a raise cause bonus @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{Damage} as usual.

Deviation

If an attack with a Cone Template fails, it goes over the targets’ heads, hits the ground, or simply falters for some reason. The GM may still decide the attack affects the area around it—perhaps a flamethrower sets a room on fire or a gas canister spews a cloud of gas—but there’s no game effect on characters or other targets this time.

If a blast template misses, it deviates 1d6″ for thrown weapons (such as grenades) and 2d6″ for fired projectiles. Multiply by 2 if the attack was made at Medium @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02range000000000]{Range}, 3 if Long, and 4 for Extreme.

Templates Without Miniatures

Use the measurements below when you need to figure out how many enemies a template might affect.

The GM can also use the Targets Affected column to determine how many enemies are hit in narrative situations, modifying the results if the targets are more spread out (highly trained agents) or bunched up (a horde of zombies).

 
Template Diameter Targets Affected
Small 4 yards 2
Medium 8 yards 3
Large 12 yards 4
Cone 18-yard-long cone 3

Next roll a d12 and read it like a clock facing to determine the direction the missile deviates. A weapon can never deviate more than half the distance to the original target (that keeps it from going behind the thrower).

Cover & Area Effect Attacks

Solid obstacles like trees or brick walls protect against area effect attacks if they’re between the origin of the blast and the GM reasonably thinks they’d apply. Reduce the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{Damage} by the amount listed on the Cover Bonus table under @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03coverandobst00]{Cover & Obstacles}

Bound and Entangled.name: Bound and Entangled
Bound and Entangled.text:
Bound & Entangled

@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03grappling00000]{Grappling} and powers like @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.Entangle]{Entangle} cause characters to be Bound and Entangled. Here’s what each of those states means and how to break free from them.

  • ENTANGLED: The victim can’t move and is @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Distracted} as long as he remains so.
  • BOUND: The victim may not move, is @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Distracted and Vulnerable} as long as he remains Bound, and cannot make physical actions other than trying to break free.

Breaking free is an @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{Action}. With success, an Entangled hero is free of one particular entanglement or grappler. A Bound character improves to Entangled with a success; with a raise, he’s free. See below for more details:

Breaking Free from a Foe: Use the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03grappling00000]{Grappling} rules in reverse to break free—the victim initiates an opposed @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll with whoever’s holding him (either may roll @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} at −2 instead to maintain or break free of the hold). If the victim’s successful, she improves her status one level, or two with a raise.

A @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Shaken} grappler maintains her hold. @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03stunned0000000]{Stunned} grapplers let go immediately.

Breaking Free from a Device: Escaping a web, net, or the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.Entangle]{Entangle} power is a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Strength} −2 roll or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll (victim’s choice) minus any penalties noted for the entanglement. The sticky web of a giant spider, for example, might note that escape attempts are made at −2 or more. This is an action, and success works just like breaking free from a foe (explained above).

Characters and allies may also destroy the entanglement (see @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03breakingthin00]{Breaking Things}). Webs, ropes, nets, and the like are generally Hardness 4 and must be cut with an edged weapon.

Breaking Things.name: Breaking Things
Breaking Things.text:
Breaking Things

Occasionally a character may want to break a solid object, such as a weapon, lock, or door. Use the wielder’s @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01characters0000]{Parry} if held, or 2 if it’s motionless. If a damage roll equals or exceeds the object’s Hardness, it’s broken, bent, shattered, or otherwise ruined. The GM decides the exact effect.

Most anything can be broken given enough time and effort, so use this system only when attempting to break things in a hurry (such as during combat rounds).

Object Hardness
Hardness Object
8 Door, Light
10 Door, Heavy
8 Lock
9 Firearm (pistol or rifle)
12 Handcuffs
10 Knife, Sword
10 Medieval Shield*
12 Modern Shield*
4 Rope

* A character must specifically state he’s trying to break a shield to do so—don’t check every time the shield-bearer is hit.

No Bonus Damage or Aces: Attacks against solid objects don’t get bonus @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{Damage} from raises, and damage rolls don’t @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Ace}. Unlike a person or complex device like a computer or a vehicle, an attack can’t hit a “vital” area on a lock or a door and thus do more damage.

Damage Types: Certain types of attacks can’t break certain types of objects. A club can’t cut a rope, for example, and a single bullet won’t destroy a door. Use common sense when determining whether or not a particular type of weapon can destroy an object.

See @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03coverandobst00]{Cover & Obstacles} to attack through barriers.

Called Shots.name: Called Shots
Called Shots.text:
Called Shots

Targeting a particular part of the body is a Called Shot. The modifier to the attack roll depends on the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03sizeandscale00]{Scale} of the target itself (not the creature it’s part of). Use the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03sizeandscale00]{Scale Modifiers} table to determine any bonus or penalty for the target’s Scale. These modifiers are already listed in parentheses below for Normal scale creatures, along with any specific game effects:

  • HAND (-4): Target may be @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03disarm00000000]{Disarmed}
  • HEAD OR VITALS (-4): Hitting the head or vital organs of living creatures adds +4 damage to the attacker’s total.
    The penalty is −5 if attempting to target the face of someone wearing an open-faced helmet (thus bypassing the helmet’s @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02armor000000000]{Armor}).
  • ITEM (?): Use the dimensions on the Scale table for items. Targeting something the size of a pistol, for example, is −4; a 3' long sword is −2.
  • LIMBS (-2): Hitting a limb has no additional special effect since it’s already accounted for by Wound and @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03movement000000]{Pace} penalties (see @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Wounds}).
  • UNARMORED AREA (?): The attack targets the unprotected area of a target otherwise covered in @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02armor000000000]{Armor}. The penalty depends on the Scale of the area. The eyeslit of a helmet is Tiny (−6), for example, while the flesh beneath the missing scale of a Huge dragon might be Very Small (−4).

Cover and Obstacles.name: Cover and Obstacles
Cover and Obstacles.text:
Cover & Obstacles

@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03attacks0000000]{Melee and ranged attacks} suffer a penalty when attempting to hit a target behind Cover, per the table below:

Cover Penalties
Penalty Cover
-2 Light Cover: A quarter of the target is obscured.
-4 Medium Cover: Half the target is obscured, or target is @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03prone000000000]{Prone}.
-6 Heavy Cover: Three-quarters of the target is obscured.
-8 Near Total Cover: The target is barely visible.

Obstacles

Sometimes characters have sufficient power to attack their foes through obstacles. (See @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03breakingthin00]{Breaking Things} to actually destroy intervening obstacles.) If a missed attack would have been successful without the Cover modifier and the GM thinks the target is likely to be hit, the obstacle acts as @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02armor000000000]{Armor}.

If the obstacle is a person or creature, subtract its @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01characters0000]{Toughness} from the attack. Use the table below as a guide for other materials.

Cover Bonus
Bonus Obstacle
+2 Heavy glass, thick leather, drywall, wooden shield, aluminum car door
+4 Sheet metal, steel car door
+6 Oak door, cinder block wall
+8 Brick wall
+10 Stone wall, bulletproof glass, tree

Defend.name: Defend
Defend.text:
Defend

A character can choose to focus all her energy and skill into defense against melee attacks with the Defend maneuver. This increases her @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01characters0000]{Parry} by +4 and takes her entire turn—she cannot perform @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03multiactions00]{Multi-Actions}. She may move normally but may not @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03movement000000]{run}. The bonus lasts until the beginning of her next turn.

Disarm.name: Disarm
Disarm.text:
Disarm

A character can try to make an opponent drop a weapon (or other object) or attempt to damage it, by making a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03attacks0000000]{melee or ranged attack}.

The attacker must first hit the object or the opponent’s limb or hand (see @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03calledshots000]{Called Shots})

If the attack hits the weapon, the attacker rolls damage normally for an item (no raise effect or Aces, see @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03breakingthin00]{Breaking Things}). The defender must make a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} roll equal to the damage or drop the item.

If the attack is against the wielder and @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Shakes or Wounds} him, the defender must make a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} roll at −2 if it hit his limb, or −4 if it hit his hand, plus any Wound penalties that result as usual. Failure means he drops whatever item is in that hand.

Distracted and Vulnerable.name: Distracted and Vulnerable
Distracted and Vulnerable.text:
Distracted & Vulnerable

Characters may be Distracted or made Vulnerable by @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03test0000000000]{Tests}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powers00000000]{Powers}, or creature effects. Both states last until the end of the character’s next turn. If a hero becomes Distracted or Vulnerable during her current turn, it lasts until the end of her next turn.

  • DISTRACTED: The hero subtracts 2 from all @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Trait Rolls} until the end of his next turn.
  • VULNERABLE: @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{Actions} and attacks against the target are made at +2 until the end of his next turn. This doesn’t stack with @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03thedrop0000000]{The Drop}—use only the highest.

Evasion.name: Evasion
Evasion.text:
Evasion

Some attacks are slow or require the user to “telegraph” their delivery, like flamethrowers or dragon’s breath. Such attacks state they may be “evaded.” If an attack doesn’t say it can be evaded, it can’t—victims are simply hit if the attack is successful and take damage.

If an attack can be evaded and the character is aware of it, he makes an @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Agility} roll at −2. Those who are successful manage to avoid the attack and take no damage. If this was an @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03areaeffectat00]{area effect attack}, the GM should place the figure to the side or rear of the template as makes sense in the situation.

Fatigue.name: Fatigue
Fatigue.text:
Fatigue

Some hazards, stress, powers, or circum­stances may cause Fatigue instead of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{Damage}. This represents mental stress or minor but lingering injuries that make a person less effective. Fatigue stacks until the victim is Incapacitated.

  • FATIGUED: The victim subtracts 1 from all @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Trait rolls}. If he takes another level of Fatigue, he’s Exhausted.
  • EXHAUSTED: The victim subtracts 2 from all Trait rolls. If he takes another level of Fatigue, he’s Incapacitated.
  • INCAPACITATED: The victim cannot perform actions and may be unconscious (GM’s call).

Recovery

Unless otherwise specified by the source, Fatigue and Exhaustion improve one level per hour. Incapacitated characters are helpless and may be unconscious (GM’s call) for [[/r 2d6]] hours. If treatment is possible (food, water, etc., depending on the source of Fatigue), and a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Healing]{Healing} roll is made, the character improves to Exhausted.

Mixed Fatigue: If a hero suffers Fatigue from different sources with different recovery times, remove one level when the effect with the shortest duration expires, then another level when the longest expires.

Hazards

Fatigue from hunger, thirst, etc., sometimes has different recovery conditions. See @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards}.

Finishing Move.name: Finishing Move
Finishing Move.text:
Finishing Move

A completely helpless victim may be dispatched with a lethal weapon of some sort as an action. This is automatic unless the GM decides there’s a special situation, such as a particularly tough or naturally armored victim, a chance for escape, and so on.

The killer must usually dispatch his foe up close and personal, but the GM may occasionally let Finishing Moves be performed at range if the situation warrants.

Firing Into Melee.name: Firing Into Melee
Firing Into Melee.text:
Firing Into Melee

Occasionally heroes have to fire into the middle of hand-to-hand fights. The trouble is that even though we might see figures standing perfectly still on the tabletop, in “reality,” they’re circling each other, wrestling back and forth, and moving erratically. For that reason, firing into a tangle of people, such as a melee, is quite dangerous. Use the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03innocentbyst00]{Innocent Bystanders} rules when this occurs.

Free Attacks.name: Free Attacks
Free Attacks.text:
Free Attacks

Some @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges}, such as @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.Counterattack]{Counterattack} and @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.First Strike]{First Strike}, or options such as @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03withdrawingf00]{Withdrawing From Melee}, allow a character to make a free attack

Free attacks are a single attack unaltered by other Edges or combat options. This is usually a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} or @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03grappling00000]{Grappling} attack, but could include @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} if the attacker is armed with a pistol or other ranged weapon that can fire in melee (see @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rangedweapon00]{Ranged Weapons In Melee}).

Ganging Up.name: Ganging Up
Ganging Up.text:
Ganging Up

Ganging up allows attackers to flank, exploit openings, and generally harass a foe. Each additional adjacent foe (who isn’t @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03stunned0000000]{Stunned}) adds +1 to all the attackers’ @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} rolls, up to a maximum of +4. If three goblins attack a single hero, for example, each of the three goblins add +2 to their Fighting rolls.

Each ally adjacent to the defender cancels out one point of Gang Up bonus from an attacker adjacent to both. This means troops in opposing lines, such as a medieval formation where each man has three adjacent foes and two adjacent allies, don’t get the bonus unless actually flanked.

Grappling.name: Grappling
Grappling.text:
Grappling

Grappling is an opposed roll between the attacker and defender’s @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics}. If the attacker wins, the foe is Entangled. With a raise, he’s Bound. (Success on a foe who was already Entangled makes him Bound.) See @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03boundandenta00]{Bound and Entangled}.

If a foe is Bound, the grappler is also @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Vulnerable} while maintaining his hold.

The @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03gangingup00000]{Ganging Up} bonus applies when grappling a defender, but other maneuvers don’t unless the Game Master rules otherwise in a specific situation.

Size Matters: If there’s a difference in Scale (see @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03sizeandscale00]{Size and Scale}) between the attacker and defender, the grappler subtracts the difference from his total (the defender does not).

Creatures may not generally grapple a foe more than two Sizes larger than themselves unless they have exceptional reach or @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} for their Size (GM’s call).

Example: A dragon (Huge +4) tries to pin a half-folk thief (Normal). The difference between Huge and Normal Scales is 4, so the dragon must subtract 4 from its @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll.
If an ogre (Normal) tries to wrestle a great white shark (Large +2), he must subtract 2 from his roll.

Crush: As an action, a grappler may make a [Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} roll as damage against a target he has @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03boundandenta00]{Entangled or Bound}. (This is a damage roll so @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03sizeandscale00]{Scale} modifiers are ignored.)

Hold.name: Hold
Hold.text:
Hold

A hero may choose to wait and see what happens by going on “Hold.” This allows her to resolve her turn later in the round if she wishes, and lasts until it’s used. If a character is on Hold when a new round begins, she’s not dealt a new @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actioncardsi00]{Action Card} but can go at any point in the round she chooses. (Discard her current card and mark her as “On Hold” with a counter of some sort.)

Shaken and Stunned: If a character is @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03stunned0000000]{Stunned} while on Hold, she immediately loses her Hold status and her turn for the round. (Shaken or Stunned characters can’t go on Hold either.)

Interrupting Actions: If a character on Hold wants to interrupt an action (including a rival who was also on Hold), she and the opponent make opposed @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} rolls. Whoever rolls highest goes first. In the rare case of a tie, the actions are simultaneous.

If the character interrupting fails, she loses her Hold status but gets a turn after the foe finishes his. She may take whatever actions she wishes when her turn comes up—she’s not locked into whatever she was trying to do when she failed to interrupt.

Illumination.name: Illumination
Illumination.text:
Illumination

Darkness conceals details and makes it more difficult to detect objects and targets. Subtract the following penalties from rolls affected by Illumination, such as attacks, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Notice]{Notice} rolls, the use of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powers00000000]{Powers}, etc.

Illumination Penalties
Penalty Lighting
-2 Dim: Twilight, light fog, night with a full moon.
-4 Dark: Typical night conditions with some ambient light from stars, a clouded or partial moon, emergency lights in an office building, a few flickering torches in a large space, etc. Targets aren’t visible outside of 10″.
-6 Pitch Darkness: Complete and total darkness (or the target is hidden or invisible). Powers that require sight may not be possible.

Improvised Weapons.name: Improvised Weapons
Improvised Weapons.text:
Improvised Weapons

Heroes often fight with objects that aren’t intended for use as weapons. Torches, vases, chairs, tankards, bottles, tools, and other mundane items are frequently pressed into service in combat.

Characters with improvised weapons count as armed but subtract 2 from attack rolls. @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02range000000000]{Range}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{Damage} and @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02minimumstren00]{Minimum Strength} are determined by type:

  • LIGHT: Metal beer stein, fist-sized rock, pistol (as a club). Range 3/6/12, Damage Str+d4, Min Str d4.
  • MEDIUM: Bowling ball, submachine gun (as a club), wooden chair. Range 2/4/8, Damage Str+d6, Min. Str d6.
  • HEAVY: Head-size rock, metal chair, duffel bag full of guns. Range 1/2/4, Damage Str+d8, Min. Str d8.

The GM can adjust the damage down a level or two if the item is softer than the examples above, like a duffel bag full of money.

Innocent Bystanders.name: Innocent Bystanders
Innocent Bystanders.text:
Innocent Bystanders

When an attacker misses a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing) roll, it may sometimes be important to see if any other targets in the line of fire were hit. The GM should only use this rule when it’s dramatically appropriate—not for every missed shot in a hail of gunfire.

Each @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{skill die} that’s a 1 hits a random victim adjacent to or directly in the line of fire to the original target. @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Wild dice} never hit innocent bystanders.

A @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03wildcardsand00]{Wild Card} must miss with his Wild Die for a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02rateoffire0000]{RoF} 1 weapon to hit an Innocent Bystander (except for @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03shotguns000000]{Shotguns}, see below).

This means it’s sometimes easier to hit an adjacent victim than the original target. That may not be entirely realistic, but is simple, dramatic, and requires some care in tight tactical situations.

  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02rateoffire0000]{Rate of Fire} 2+ or @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03shotguns000000]{Shotguns}: Weapons that spray bullets or buckshot are much more likely to hit others. Each skill die that rolls a 1 or a 2 hits a bystander.

Mounted Combat.name: Mounted Combat
Mounted Combat.text:
Mounted Combat

Characters @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} from horseback (or other strange beasts) have certain advantages and disadvantages in combat, as described below.

Mounts aren’t dealt @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actioncardsi00]{Action Cards}—they act with their riders. Animals may attack any threat to their front during their rider’s action.

Horsemanship: Characters who wish to fight from horseback must use the lowest of their @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Riding]{Riding} skills. This makes it important for cavalrymen to actually be able to ride well!

Falling: If a character is @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Shaken}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03stunned0000000]{Stunned}, or @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Wounded} while mounted, or his mount is @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Incapacitated}, he must make a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Riding]{Riding} roll. If he fails, he falls. If the mount was running (GM’s call), the rider suffers 2d4 damage (2d6 with a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Critical Failure)}.

Missed @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03attacks0000000]{Ranged Attacks}: Mounts and riders are affected by the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03innocentbyst00]{Innocent Bystander} rules. If a shot intended at a rider rolls a 1, it hits the horse instead.

@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Wounded} Mounts: When an animal is @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Wounded}, it rears or bucks. A rider must make a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Riding]{Riding} roll to stay mounted, or falls as above.

Charging

A rider on a charging horse adds +4 to his damage roll with a successful @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} attack. To be considered charging, the rider must have moved at least 6″ or more in a relatively straight line toward his foe.

Setting Weapons: A weapon with a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02reach000000000]{Reach} of 1 or greater can be “set” against a cavalry attack. To do so, the attacker must be on @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03hold0000000000]{Hold} and win an opposed @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll to interrupt as usual. Whoever has the most @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02reach000000000]{Reach} adds +2 to his roll.

The winner attacks first. If successful, he adds the +4 charge bonus to his damage (whether he’s the rider or not).

Multi-Actions.name: Multi-Actions
Multi-Actions.text:
Multi-Actions

Characters can perform up to three @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{actions} on their turn. Each additional action beyond the first inflicts a −2 penalty to all actions. Taking two actions, for example, incurs a −2 penalty to both, and three actions is a −4 penalty.

@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03wildcardsand00]{Wild Cards} get their Wild Die on each action as usual.

All actions must be declared at the start of the turn and before any dice are rolled. Penalties remain even if a later action doesn’t happen (usually because it was dependent on an earlier success).

Movement and Multiple Actions: A chara­cter may perform multiple actions at different points in his @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03movement000000]{Movement}.

Free Actions: Multi-Action penalties do not apply to @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{free actions}, and free actions never inflict a penalty on other actions.

Natural Weapons.name: Natural Weapons
Natural Weapons.text:
Natural Weapons

Creatures with natural weapons such as fangs, claws, or horns may attack with any or all of them using their @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} skill. Damage is stated for character races and beasts in their various descriptions.

Creatures with natural weapons are always considered armed. This means they aren’t an @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03unarmeddefen00]{Unarmed Defender} and foes @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} with @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03twoweapons0000]{Two Weapons} gain no advantage against them. Here are a few additional notes for each type of attack:

  • BITE: The creature may bite a target it’s grappled (most attackers can only crush their prey, see @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03grappling00000]{Grappling}).
  • CLAWS: +2 to @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (climbing) rolls on any rough or soft surface (not sheer steel, glass, etc.).
  • HORNS: Add +4 @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{Damage} at the end of one @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} action in which it @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03movement000000]{Runs}, moves at least 5″(10 yards), and successfully hits with its horns.

Nonlethal Damage.name: Nonlethal Damage
Nonlethal Damage.text:
Nonlethal Damage

A character who wants to beat someone up without killing them can choose to do nonlethal damage. This requires the attacker use only his fists or a blunt weapon of some sort. Edged weapons may be used if they have a flat side, but this subtracts −1 from the attacker’s @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} rolls.

Nonlethal damage causes @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Wounds} as usual, but if a character is rendered @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Incapacitated} he’s knocked out for 1d6 hours instead.

Nonlethal @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Wounds} are otherwise treated exactly as lethal @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Wounds}. This means it’s much easier to render an Extra unconscious than a Wild Card (See @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03wildcardsand00]{Wild Cards and Extras}). This is intentional, and should work well for most genres where heroes can take multiple punches before going down for the count, but most “mooks” go out with one or two good punches.

Off-Hand Attacks.name: Off-Hand Attacks
Off-Hand Attacks.text:
Off-Hand Attacks

Characters are assumed to be right-handed unless the player decides otherwise. Actions that require precise eye-hand coordination, such as @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting}, suffer a −2 penalty when done solely with the off-hand.

Off-hand weapons don’t add their @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02parry000000000]{Parry} bonus unless the hero is @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.Ambidextrous]{Ambidextrous}.

Prone.name: Prone
Prone.text:
Prone

Ranged attacks suffer a −4 penalty to hit prone characters from a range of 3″ or greater (this does not stack with @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03coverandobst00]{Cover)} and subtract four points of damage from @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03areaeffectat00]{Area Effect attacks}.

If a prone defender is caught in melee, his @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01characters0000]{Parry} is reduced by 2 and he must subtract 2 from his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} rolls.

Standing costs a character 2″ of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03movement000000]{Movement}.

Push.name: Push
Push.text:
Push

Sometimes characters may want to push a foe in hopes of knocking him out of position, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03prone000000000]{prone}, or even into a deadly @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{hazard}.

Pushing a foe is an @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{opposed roll} of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength}. If the attacker is successful he pushes the foe back up to 1″ (two yards). With a raise, increase the distance to 2″ (four yards). Double either distance if the attacker’s @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03sizeandscale00]{Scale} is larger than the foe’s.

A character who’s successfully Pushed must make an @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll (at −2 if the attacker got a raise) or be knocked @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03prone000000000]{prone}.

Running: If the attacker ran at least 2″ (four yards) before the Push, he adds +2 to his total.

Size Matters: Creatures may not generally Push a foe more than two @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03sizeandscale00]{Sizes} larger then themselves unless they have exceptional @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} for their Size (GM’s call).

Skill: The attacker or defender may roll @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} instead of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} if they choose.

Shields: Attackers and defenders add their @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02shields0000000]{shield’s Parry bonus} to their @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} (or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics}) rolls when pushing.

Ranged Weapons In Melee.name: Ranged Weapons In Melee
Ranged Weapons In Melee.text:
Ranged Weapons In Melee

Heroes may fire ranged weapons when engaged in melee with a few caveats:

  • The attacker may only use a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powers00000000]{power} or a one-handed ranged weapon (such as a firearm no larger than a pistol) when in melee. He may not fire rifles or other “long arms.” The TN is the defender’s @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01characters0000]{Parry} instead of Short Range as he struggles, wrestles back and forth, etc.
  • If attacking a non-adjacent target with a ranged attack while in melee, the attacker instantly becomes @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Vulnerable}.

Readying Weapons.name: Readying Weapons
Readying Weapons.text:
Readying Weapons

Characters may “ready” up to two items per turn as a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{free action}. Readying means drawing, holstering, or otherwise moving an item into or out of a familiar and easy-to-reach location.

Each additional item readied is an @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{action}, as is readying an item from a difficult location such as an ankle holster, off the floor after being @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03disarm00000000]{disarmed}, or other exten­uating circumstances.

Recoil.name: Recoil
Recoil.text:
Recoil

Unless it says otherwise in its description, firing at a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02rateoffire0000]{Rate of Fire} greater than 1 in one @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{action} causes Recoil, a −2 penalty to the attacker’s @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} rolls. A submachine gun with a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02rateoffire0000]{Rate of Fire} of 3, for example, causes Recoil unless its user fires only a single shot.

Recoil isn’t cumulative between @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{actions}. If a character fires three shots (@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02rateoffire0000]{RoF} 3) on one action and triggers the Recoil penalty, he ignores it on a second action if he only fires a single shot.

Reloading.name: Reloading
Reloading.text:
Reloading

Nocking an arrow or loading a stone in a sling are @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{free actions} that may be performed once per @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{action}. Reloading a crossbow bolt, clip, magazine, speed loader, or single bullet so that it’s ready to fire (chambered, cocked, etc.) is an action.

Some weapons are slower to reload, like heavy crossbows or black powder weapons. They require a number of actions to reload, listed as “Reload X” in their description.

Example: Gabe fires a heavy crossbow (Reload 2) as part of a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03multiactions00]{Multi-Action}, using his other two actions that turn to reload. Since this is three actions, his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} roll is made at −4. On the following round, he can fire again at no penalty.

Running & Reloading: Characters who @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03movement000000]{run} and load must make an @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Agility} roll (at the usual −2 penalty for running). Failure means no progress toward reloading was made that action.

Shotguns.name: Shotguns
Shotguns.text:
Shotguns

Shotguns fire a spread of metal “shot,” and so do more @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{Damage} at close @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02range000000000]{Range} where more of the shot hits the target. Because of this, shotguns add +2 to the user’s @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} rolls and cause 3d6 @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{Damage} at Short @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02range000000000]{Range}, 2d6 at Medium, and 1d6 at Long. Shotguns may not be fired at Extreme @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02range000000000]{Range}.

Double Barrels: Some shotguns have two barrels welded side-by-side. If an attacker wants to fire both barrels at the same target, roll @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{Damage} once and add +4.

Slugs: Shotguns can also fire slugs. The attacker doesn’t get the +2 shotgun bonus to his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} roll, but the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{Damage} is 2d10 regardless of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02range000000000]{Range} (and they may be fired at Extreme @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02range000000000]{Range}). @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03innocentbyst00]{Innocent Bystanders} are hit only on a 1 (instead of 1 or 2).

Size and Scale.name: Size and Scale
Size and Scale.text:
Size & Scale

Characters and creatures have a Size ranging from −4 for very small beings up to Size 20 and higher for massive behemoths. Specific creature Sizes are listed in their statistics, and explained on the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor06bestia.JournalEntryPage.06sizetable00000]{Size Table}.

The @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor06bestia.JournalEntryPage.06sizetable00000]{Size Table} lists seven different “Scales,” from Tiny to Gargantuan, and the Scale Modifier that goes with each.

When creatures of different Scales attack each other, the smaller creature adds the difference between its Scale and its target to its attacks. A Tiny fairy (−6 Scale modifier), for example, adds +10 to hurl a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.Bolt]{Bolt} at a Huge dragon (+4).

The larger creature subtracts the difference from its attacks. A Very Small eagle (−4) subtracts 2 from its Fighting totals when attacking a Tiny fairy (−6).

Scale Modifiers
Modifier Scale & Examples
-6 Tiny: Armor join, baseball, mouse
-4 Very Small: Human hand or head, basketball, house cat
-2 Small: Human limb, bobcat
— Normal: Human, motorc­ycle, bull, horse
+2 Large: Hippo, most vehicles
+4 Huge: Dragon, whale
+6 Gargantuan: Building, kaiju, ship

@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03calledshots000]{Called Shots} & Target Size

Use the Scale of the target when making @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03calledshots000]{called shots} against creatures, not their Scale. If a hero wants to blast the eye of a Huge robot destroying the city, for example, use the Scale of the eye, not the robot. If the eye is about the size of a car, the hero adds +2 to his roll because a car is Large, a +2 bonus.

Hitting the vital areas have extra effects listed under @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03calledshots000]{Called Shots}.

Speed.name: Speed
Speed.text:
Speed

Characters occasionally need to attack fast-moving targets. If the relative speed between attacker and defender is 60 Miles per Hour (MPH) or more, apply the Relative Speed Penalty:

Relative Speed Penalty
Penalty Target's Relative Speed Is...
-1 60 MPH+
-2 120 MPH+
-4 240 MPH+
-6 Mach 1+
-8 Mach 2+
-10 Near Light Speed+
  • Multiply MPH by 1.5 to get @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03movement000000]{Pace}
  • Divide @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03movement000000]{Pace} by 1.5 to get MPH

Stunned.name: Stunned
Stunned.text:
Stunned

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-equipment.Stun Gun]{Stun guns}, creature abilities, the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.Stun]{stun} power, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04electricity000]{electrical} hazards, or other shocks to the brain or nervous system make a character essentially helpless until they manage to shake it off.

Stunned Characters

  • Are @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Distracted} (this is removed at the end of the victim's next turn as usual)
  • Are @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Vulnerable} (this remains until they recover from being Stunned)
  • Fall @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03prone000000000]{Prone} (or to their knees, GM’s call)
  • Can’t @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03movement000000]{move} or take any @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{actions}
  • Don’t count toward the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03gangingup00000]{Gang Up} bonus

Recovery: At the start of a Stunned character’s turn, he makes a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Vigor} roll as a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{free action}. Success means he’s no longer Stunned but remains @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Vulnerable} until the end of his next turn. With a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{raise}, his @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Vulnerable} state goes away at the end of this turn.

Support.name: Support
Support.text:
Support

Sometimes characters may want to cooperate or help an ally with a task. If so, and the GM decides it’s possible, supporting characters roll the relevant @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{skill} (on their action if the game is in rounds) and declare which of their ally’s skills they’re attempting to Support.

Success grants the ally +1 to one  @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{skill} total this round, and a raise adds +2. A Critical Failure on the support roll subtracts 2 from the lead’s total—sometimes extra hands just get in the way!

Remove all Support bonuses at the end of the recipient’s turn, whether he used them or not (perhaps by taking an action different than the one he was Supported for).

The maximum bonus from all Support rolls is +4. @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} checks are an exception and have no maximum bonus since more muscle can always manage more mass.

Players and GMs should be creative when making Support rolls. An adventurer with @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Survival]{Survival}, for example, might make a roll to find useful herbs for an ally attempting a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.Healing]{Healing} check, or a galactic explorer with @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Science]{Science} might calculate slingshot vectors that help a friend make a tricky @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Piloting]{Piloting} roll.

General encouragement (a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} roll) such as “You can do it!” or “Check your six!” are perfectly acceptable, but at the GM’s discretion lose effectiveness if repeated.

Example: Gabe is the driver in a chase. Red points out a shortcut by yelling, “Take the next left!” She rolls @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Common Knowledge]{Common Knowledge} and gets a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{raise}. Gabe adds +2 to his next @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Driving]{Driving} roll. Later on, Red is hit by a ricochet and is @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Shaken}. Gabe yells, “Toughen up, cowgirl! This ain’t your first rodeo!” and makes a Persuasion roll. He gets a success and Red adds +1 to her upcoming Spirit total to recover from being @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Shaken}.

Support vs. @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03test0000000000]{Test}

The Support option can be used against an opponent narratively, but the only effect it can have is as detailed above. If a character wants to “trip up” an ogre to help a friend make a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} roll against it, for example, she can add +1 or +2 to his roll, but she doesn’t actually trip the ogre. It’s not made @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03prone000000000]{prone}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Distracted}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{vulnerable}, or @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Shaken} as it might if she had used the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03test0000000000]{Test} option.

The advantage for a player in making a Support roll over a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03test0000000000]{Test} is to help an ally and avoid a more difficult @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{opposed roll} for the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03test0000000000]{Test} (even though narratively it might seem like it should be an @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{opposed roll}).

Suppresive Fire.name: Suppresive Fire
Suppresive Fire.text:
Suppresive Fire

Suppressive Fire turns a firearm or other rapid-firing weapon into @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03areaeffectat00]{Area Effect Attacks}. It trades accuracy for a hail of ammo to keep the enemies’ heads down.

A weapon must be able to fire at least as rapidly as a revolver and can’t require reloading in between shots.

Suppressive Fire uses three times the usual number of bullets for its @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02rateoffire0000]{Rate of Fire} and always incurs @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03recoil00000000]{Recoil} regardless of the weapon’s original @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02rateoffire0000]{Rate of Fire} (the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.Rock and Roll!]{Rock and Roll!} Edge, bipods, and tripods negate @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03recoil00000000]{Recoil} as usual).

To make the attack, the shooter places a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03areaeffectat00]{Medium Blast Template} on the tabletop and makes a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} roll (a single @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} die regardless of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02rateoffire0000]{Rate of Fire}—RoF comes into Maximum Casualties, below.) Figure @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02range000000000]{Range}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03illumination00]{Illumination}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03recoil00000000]{Recoil}, etc., as usual, to the center of the template.

Next compare the total to each target in the template and consider any modifiers that apply to each (@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03coverandobst00]{Cover}, the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.Dodge]{Dodge} Edge, the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.Deflection]{deflection} power, etc.). Success means the target is @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Distracted}, and a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{raise} means he’s actually hit (no bonus @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{damage} is possible from Suppressive Fire).

Maximum Casualties: Every target under the template can be @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Distracted}, but it can only cause @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{damage} to a number of targets equal to the weapon’s @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02rateoffire0000]{Rate of Fire}. The attacker chooses which targets are hit among his possible choices.

Example: Gabe fires a minigun at a group of rampaging insectoids. He places a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03areaeffectat00]{Medium Blast Template} over five of them and rolls his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} die and a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Wild die}. He has the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.Rock and Roll!]{Rock and Roll!} Edge so he ignores @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03recoil00000000]{Recoil} but still subtracts 2 from his total for Medium Range. He ends up with a 9 on his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} roll.

Two of the insectoids were behind a large rock and get Medium @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03coverandobst00]{Cover}. That subtracts 4 from the total so that’s a single success—they’re @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Distracted}.

Three of the targets were out in the open so they’re hit with a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{raise}. Gabe can hit up to five given his weapon’s @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02rateoffire0000]{RoF}, so all three take @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{damage}.

The @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02rateoffire0000]{Rate of Fire} of 5 means each “shot” is 40 bullets, multiplied by three for Suppressive Fire. That’s 120 bullets, which is why miniguns come loaded with lots of ammo!

Surprise.name: Surprise
Surprise.text:
Surprise

Combat often starts before everyone involved is prepared. An ambush, a sudden double-cross, or a trap might all give one side in a fight an edge over the other.

When this happens, the ambushers are automatically on @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03hold0000000000]{Hold}. Deal them in as usual anyway in case one of them gets a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actioncardsi00]{Joker}.

The victims of the attack make a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Notice]{Notice} roll (if they haven’t already, perhaps from ambushers sneaking up on them). Those who make it are dealt in as usual. Those who fail get no @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actioncardsi00]{Action Card} and can’t act in the first round of combat.

Test.name: Test
Test.text:
Test

The @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03support0000000]{Support} option allows a character to help out her allies. Test is the opposite—it lets him make things more difficult for his foes! Tests include embarrassing an opponent, throwing sand in his eyes, staring him down with a steely gaze, or anything else a clever player can think of to rattle his enemy and put him off-balance.

To perform a Test, the player describes the action and works with the GM to determine the most appropriate skill to roll for it. Tests are resisted instinctively, so the “attacker’s” @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{skill roll} is opposed by the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{attribute} it’s linked to. Tripping someone is an @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll versus @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Agility} since that’s what @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} is linked to. @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} is linked to @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Smarts}, so verbally humiliating someone is resisted by that @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{attribute}. @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}, when used as a Test instead of an actual attack, isn’t compared to @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01characters0000]{Parry}—it’s opposed by @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Agility}.

If the attacker wins the opposed roll, he can choose to make his foe @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Distracted or Vulnerable}. If he wins with a raise, the target is also @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Shaken} or there may be other subjective effects as the GM allows, such as a tripped foe being knocked prone.

Modifiers: The GM must determine which modifiers apply to a Test. @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting}, for example, should include @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02range000000000]{Range}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03coverandobst00]{Cover}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03illumination00]{Illumination}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03recoil00000000]{Recoil}, etc. A hero with a bonus to his @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01characters0000]{Parry} does not add it to his @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Agility} when challenged with a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} roll, however, because the defender resists with @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Agility}—not his @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01characters0000]{Parry}.

Take the details into consideration as well—using @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} to hit a rival’s ego where it hurts, for example, might be worth a +2 bonus to the attacker.

Repetition: Using the same or similar action repeatedly quickly grows less effective, so the GM should apply a steep penalty if a character’s Tests become repetitive (or disallow it entirely).

Additional Dice: If characters have addi­tional dice for a Test, such as when using a weapon with a high @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02rateoffire0000]{Rate of Fire}, he may roll all the dice but takes only the highest as his Test total. He doesn’t get multiple results and he can’t spread them out to other targets.

The Drop.name: The Drop
The Drop.text:
The Drop

Sometimes an attacker is able to catch a foe off-guard and gets “The Drop” on him. The GM decides when this is in effect—usually it’s when the victim is bound or completely unaware of an attack. The Drop usually happens up close but the GM can also allow it in other situations as she sees fit (a sniper attacking an unaware and stationary target).

The Drop adds +4 to a character’s attack and @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{damage} rolls against that target for one @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03actions0000000]{action}.

Knockout Blow: If a character takes enough @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{damage} to be @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Shaken} or worse from an attacker with The Drop on him, he must make a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Vigor} roll (at −2 if the attack was to the head) or be knocked unconscious.

KO’ed characters stay that way for about half an hour or until the GM decides it’s dramatically appropriate to wake up. Note that Knockout Blows come from any kind of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02damage00000000]{damage}, not just blows to the head!

Touch Attack.name: Touch Attack
Touch Attack.text:
Touch Attack

A character who simply wants to touch a foe (usually to deliver a magical effect of some kind) may add +2 to his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} roll.

Two Weapons.name: Two Weapons
Two Weapons.text:
Two Weapons

A character armed with two melee weapons adds +1 to his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} rolls if his foe has a single weapon or is @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03unarmeddefen00]{unarmed}, and has no shield. It adds no bonus against creatures with @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03naturalweapo00]{Natural Weapons}.

Wielding two firearms offers no special advantage other than additional ammunition.

Characters who want to specialize further can take the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.Two-Fisted]{Two-Fisted} or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.Two-Gun Kid]{Two-Gun Kid} Edge.

Unarmed Defender.name: Unarmed Defender
Unarmed Defender.text:
Unarmed Defender

It’s difficult to @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01characters0000]{Parry} a blade with one’s bare hands. An attacker armed with a melee weapon adds +2 to his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} attacks if his foe has no weapon or shield. (This doesn’t stack with @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03thedrop0000000]{The Drop}.)

Unstable Platform.name: Unstable Platform
Unstable Platform.text:
Unstable Platform

A character attempting to @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{fire} or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{throw} a ranged weapon from the back of a horse or other mount, a moving vehicle, or other “unstable platform” subtracts 2 from his total.

Vehicles.name: Vehicles
Vehicles.text:
Vehicles

Sample lists of vehicles (@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02aircrafttabl00]{aircraft}, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02groundvehicl00]{ground vehicles}, and @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02watercraftta00]{watercraft}) are included in Chapter Two (Gear) along with any relevant @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02vehiclenotes00].

Vehicular weapons work just like any other—characters make @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} rolls to hit a target and roll damage if successful (plus a bonus die if they hit with a raise). Unless a character has the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.Steady Hands]{Steady Hands} Edge, don’t forget the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03unstableplat00]{Unstable Platform} penalty.

Damage and how to handle vehicles on the tabletop are covered under @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04chasesandveh00]{Chases and Vehicles}.

Wild Attack.name: Wild Attack
Wild Attack.text:
Wild Attack

Sometimes a desperate character may want to throw caution to the wind and attack with everything he’s got.

A Wild Attack adds +2 to the character’s @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} attacks and resulting damage rolls for the turn, but he is @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Vulnerable} until the end of his next turn (not this one).

Wild Attacks can be used with multiple attacks, such as from @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03multiactions00]{Multi-Actions} or the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.Frenzy]{Frenzy} and @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.Sweep]{Sweep} Edges.

Withdrawing From Melee.name: Withdrawing From Melee
Withdrawing From Melee.text:
Withdrawing From Melee

Whenever a character retreats from melee, all adjacent non-@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Shaken} and non-@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03stunned0000000]{Stunned} opponents get an immediate Free Attack (see @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03freeattacks000]{Free Attacks}).

Example: Red is surrounded by five strange xenos and must get to a wounded Gabe. She takes the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03defend00000000]{Defend} option (increasing her @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01characters0000]{Parry} by +4) and backs away. All five xenos get a Free Attack, at +4 for @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03gangingup00000]{Ganging Up}. Fortunately, Red’s high @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01characters0000]{Parry} fends them off and she makes her way to her injured friend.

Blast Templates.name: Blast Templates
Blast Templates.text:
Blast Templates

The following are the sizes of the blast templates in inches for use on a grid. If you're using a non-1" grid, be sure to scale your templates appropriately.

Please refer to the Savage Worlds documentation for your preferred VTT to learn how to apply these automatically to the tabletop.

  • Cone Templates are 9" long and 3" wide at their widest point
  • Large Burst Templates are 6" in diameter
  • Medium Burst Templates are 4" in diameter
  • Small Burst Templates are 2" in diameter.
  • The Turning Template is a 45 degree angle.

Adventure Toolkit.name: Adventure Toolkit
Adventure Toolkit.text:
The Adventure Toolkit

The following chapter contains tools the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor07gamema.JournalEntryPage.07gamemasterin00]{Game Master} can use for all the special situations that often come up in a game, such as:

  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04allies00000000]{ALLIES}: Managing Extras under the player character’s control.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04chasesandveh00]{CHASES & VEHICLES}: Dynamic and thrilling chases on foot, in cars, or on motorcycles, or dogfights between massive fleets of starships!
  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04dramatictask00]{DRAMATIC TASKS}: Add tension and drama to situations like defusing a bomb or hacking a computer.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04fear0000000000]{FEAR}: The effects of overwhelming terror.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{HAZARDS}: The effects of scorching heat, bitter cold, radiation, and more.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04interludes0000]{INTERLUDES}: Narrative storytelling for long trips or to reveal bits about the player characters’ backstories.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04massbattles000]{MASS BATTLES}: Desperate last stands against incredible odds between armies.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04networking0000]{NETWORKING}: Gathering information or asking for favors.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04quickencount00]{QUICK ENCOUNTERS}: A fast and easy way to resolve fights, heists, or capers when pressed for time.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04settingrules00]{SETTING RULES}: A host of special rules you can use to customize your setting!
  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04socialconfli00]{SOCIAL CONFLICT}: Run a court trial, plead for aid, or convince a crowd.
  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04travel00000000]{TRAVEL}: Figure out how long it takes for the party to cross your savage world!
  • @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04wealth00000000]{WEALTH}: An optional system for those who don’t want to worry about tracking income and expenses.

Allies.name: Allies
Allies.text:
Allies

Allies play a big part in many Savage Worlds games. They serve as troops under your hero’s command in Weird Wars, loyal retainers in fantasy settings, or fellow fighters in glorious rebellions against oppression.

When to Use These Rules: Use these rules to help keep track of the party’s followers and give them a little extra personality to play off of as well.

The Basics: Players create, control, and track their own followers and nonplayer character allies.

Using Allies

Keeping up with allies in Savage Worlds is simple. Just download the Ally Sheet from our website and fill in the blanks.

Allied @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03wildcardsand00]{Extras} are divided up among all the players to control. This is a very important part of Savage Worlds because our settings often feature allied bands of skilled hirelings, fellow grunts, or loyal retainers, and the game is designed to handle them quickly and easily. It’s also designed for the players to control them—not the Game Master.

It doesn’t matter whether or not the characters control the allies, only that the players do. This keeps everyone involved in the action even if his hero is out of the fight, and makes running large combats much easier and more fun for everyone. Of course the GM can always take charge of Extras when the need arises, but with good roleplayers this should rarely be necessary.

Allied Personalities

You can add a little flavor to your allies by rolling on the Allied Personalities table. Jot down the keyword on the Ally Sheet so you and your Game Master have a little insight into each particular ally’s character.

Consider these general impressions with no particular game effect. They help both the player and GM decide just how an ally might react in a given situation.
